statement: For any set P of n points in the plane with no three collinear, the number of distinct distances D(P) satisfies D(P) >= floor(n/2).
win_condition: Find a set P with |P|=n points in the plane, no three collinear, such that D(P) < floor(n/2).
background: The regular n-gon achieves D(P) = floor(n/2). The pinned variant (fixing one point and counting distances from it) has been disproved with a finite counterexample using two concentric regular N-gons. The global conjecture remains open.
known_bounds: Regular n-gon gives D(P) = floor(n/2). This is conjectured to be minimal.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Try two concentric regular N-gons first (Family B from context document)
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Lowest parameter dimension. Pinned counterexample used this family. Parameters reduce to (r, Delta) where constraints are quadratic in r.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Focus on odd N values where cyclotomic algebra is richer
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Special values like N=5,7,9,21 have low-degree trigonometric identities that create more distance collisions.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Try 3-layer constructions (m=3) only after m=2 is exhausted
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Parameter space grows with layers. Constraint one extra parameter at a time.

prior_attempts.description: Exhaustive 2-layer C_N scan for odd N (from Erdos Problems forum thread)
prior_attempts.parameter_range: N in [3, 249], r from constraint-derived algebraic points
prior_attempts.what_was_ruled_out: All 2-layer C_N configs with odd N <= 249 and degree <= 4 constraint-derived r values
